ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to write and understand arguments; knowledge of Western canon.

My literary analysis abilities were greatly improved, as was my ability to determine how much of a text you need to read to understand the nature of the work (necessitated by the high volume of required reading for this class and the Directed Studies program in general).  I also gained a greater appreciation for literature as a discipline and how it has evolved through time.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Engaging content; could have better lectures.

Strengths: exposure to many seminal works of humankind, a fascinating sweep through historical literature, development of being able to execute high-quality reading and writing under pressure (high volume of both).  

Weaknesses: You don't really get to truly appreciate any of the individual works because you blow through them so fast, but you do at least get exposure to them and enough information and discussion to revisit them later.  I also felt that there was a lack of historical context that would allow you to get more value out of the texts ingrained within the course and you had to do your own research or rely on your professor for this context.  There were also some texts towards the end of the semester that seem like they were inserted solely to combat the critique that DS is so exclusively Western-focused, as they were not presented with the rest of the course in an integrated way and I felt I lacked adequate context for these works and cultures.  In the future, more of an introduction to these cultures would smooth the currently abrupt transition from Ancient Greece/Rome smoother and allow students to get much more out of the texts.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, couldn't recommend more for someone interested in these books.

Absolutely!  That is, if you are truly interested in reading, discussing, and analyzing some of the most enduring texts humanity has produced.  If so, this will be one of the best classes you will ever take.  That said, it is obviously a lot of reading and writing, so don't do DS if you're not a fan of both.
